body: I don't like the presentation as "Get out of hell free" because it implies that you don't change at all, when in fact your entire worldview and values are radically altered. Plus hell is unlikely to be a real thing.
body_html: I don't like the presentation as "Get out of hell free" because it implies that you don't change at all, when in fact your entire worldview and values are radically altered. Plus hell is unlikely to be a real thing.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body: Most occurrences of "hell" in the OT actually mean the grave. In the NT it's either Hades, which is the same thing, or Gehenna, which is actually a valley where junk was burned non-stop. "Unquenchable fire" is therefore an allusion to the constant incineration of garbage and a metaphor for destruction.
body_html: Most occurrences of "hell" in the OT actually mean the grave. In the NT it's either Hades, which is the same thing, or Gehenna, which is actually a valley where junk was burned non-stop. "Unquenchable fire" is therefore an allusion to the constant incineration of garbage and a metaphor for destruction.
